nbme_correct_explanation: Interstitial lung disease (ILD) refers to the heterogeneous group of disorders that result in pulmonary fibrosis and progressively impaired lung function. There are a wide variety of underlying causes, including infections, occupational and environmental exposures, drug-induced pulmonary toxicity, radiation-induced lung injury, connective tissue disorders, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and idiopathic disease. Patients classically present with progressive dyspnea and chronic nonproductive cough. Inspiratory crackles and hypertrophic osteoarthritis may be present on physical examination. Definitive diagnosis requires lung biopsy and histologic examination, but this is not always performed as it does not often change management. Typically, the diagnosis is made on the basis of clinical and radiological findings. A high-resolution CT scan of the chest is recommended for all patients to provide diagnostic support. Pulmonary function testing is often used to assess and monitor disease severity. ILD is associated with a restrictive pattern on spirometry and reduced diffusion capacity caused by inflammation and destruction of lung parenchyma and alveoli.
nbme_incorrect_explanation: PPD skin test (Choice A) is used to test for exposure to tuberculosis. Tuberculosis can manifest in a variety of ways and can mimic interstitial lung disease in presentation and imaging. A history of tuberculosis is a risk factor for developing interstitial lung disease, and the patient should be evaluated for any history of exposure; however, the initial diagnostic test is a high-resolution CT scan. Similarly, serum rheumatoid factor assay (Choice B) may be checked as part of a panel to evaluate for autoimmune disease as a potential underlying cause of a patient's interstitial lung disease. Exercise stress test (Choice C) and ventilation-perfusion lung scans (Choice E) are not commonly used in the diagnostic work-up or management of interstitial lung disease.

nbme_correct_explanation: Obesity-hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) is the most likely cause of this patient's nocturia. OHS is occasionally encountered in patients with a BMI over 30 kg/m2 , and it is common in patients with a BMI over 50 kg/m2. Chronic alveolar hypoventilation leads to both hypercapnia and hypoxemia. Hypercapnia results in a compensatory metabolic alkalosis, which manifests as an increased serum bicarbonate concentration, while chronic hypoxemia can lead to pulmonary hypertension and polycythemia. When severe, resting hypoxemia may be apparent. Pulmonary function tests are often done to exclude other causes of hypoventilation and hypercapnia. These studies are frequently normal, although they may disclose varying degrees of restrictive lung disease and reduced diffusing capacity. There is a substantial overlap with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) as well, but OSA does not cause chronic hypercapnia. Because of substantial clinical overlap, it is common for patients to exhibit symptoms of hypersomnolence, morning headaches, fatigue, snoring, and nocturia. Nocturia is thought to occur because of an increased circulating concentration of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP), which is either triggered by atrial distention resulting from an increasingly negative intrathoracic pressure that develops when breathing is occluded during sleep, or from hypoxia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction. In either case, ANP inhibits the release of antidiuretic hormone leading to nocturia through increased excretion of free water. The diagnosis of OHS can be made in a patient with a BMI over 30 kg/m2 with documented alveolar hypoventilation while awake after exclusion of competing diagnoses.

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (Choice A) often presents with exertional dyspnea and coughing or wheezing, and sometimes with resting hypoxemia. It is more common in patients who smoke cigarettes and is not as likely to present with daytime somnolence, nocturia, and daytime fatigue. COPD can be diagnosed using spirometry.

Cystitis (Choice B) is unlikely to be the cause of this patient's nocturia because she does not have symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, or urgency.

Hypothyroidism (Choice C) can substantially worsen symptoms of OSA, but only in severe cases that lead to respiratory muscle myopathy. While this patient's weight gain could potentially be secondary to hypothyroidism, her other clinical signs and symptoms support a diagnosis of OHS.

Narcolepsy (Choice D) is a condition caused by decreased concentrations of the neuropeptides orexin-A and orexin-B. Patients present with cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, sleep paralysis, and daytime somnolence. It is more common in patients under the age of 40 years.

Clinical severity can be determined based on assessment of symptoms, which in this case include fever and abdominal pain, both of which are consistent with moderate to severe disease. Disease activity is largely based on patient-reported symptoms and is a spectrum from clinical remission to mild, moderate, severe, or fulminant disease. Patients with mild disease may have minimal weight loss but no systemic symptoms, while patients with moderate to severe disease can present with abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, nausea or vomiting, and fever. Fulminant disease is marked by the presence of severe symptoms despite the use of steroids or biologic agents, and it is often associated with complications including abscess formation, peritonitis, stricture, or bowel obstruction. nbme_correct_explanation: This patient with numerous duodenal ulcers most likely has a gastrin-secreting tumor. Gastrin is physiologically produced by G cells in the gastric antrum and functions to stimulate parietal cells within the gastric body to produce hydrochloric acid. Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, the constellation of findings associated with gastrinoma, stems from a gastrinsecreting tumor typically located within the pancreas or duodenum. It results in excessive production of acid by the gastric parietal cells. This can lead to recurrent, chronic duodenal or jejunal ulcers, which can present with abdominal pain, diarrhea secondary to malabsorption, and possible hematemesis, melena, or hematochezia. The initial step in evaluation of a gastrinoma is to measure the serum gastrin concentration. If abnormal, a secretin stimulation test should be performed, which would disclose increased gastrin concentrations after administration of secretin, opposite of the normal, physiologic inhibition. Cross-sectional imaging should then be performed to determine the location of the gastrinoma for planning of surgical resection. In the meantime, treatment with proton pump inhibitors is indicated to reduce gastric acidity.
nbme_incorrect_explanation:
Bowel lymphoma (Choice A) may occur at any point along the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus, but the most common sites are the stomach and the small bowel. Most of these tumors are of B-lymphocyte origin, and symptoms of abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, and anorexia share similar features with other diseases. The presence of numerous duodenal ulcers on endoscopy is more suggestive of a gastrinoma than lymphoma in this patient.
Parathyroid adenomas (Choice C) are occasionally found in association with gastrinomas or other neuroendocrine tumors in patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome type-I. While a functional parathyroid adenoma can lead to hypercalcemia, which may cause abdominal pain, it does not explain this patient's duodenal ulcers.
Pheochromocytoma (Choice D) presents with episodic headaches, sweating, palpitations, tremors, agitation, tachycardia, tachypnea, and treatment-refractory hypertension. It is a tumor of the adrenal medulla, and is marked by the functional secretion of epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine, which cause episodic hyperadrenergic symptoms. It does not cause duodenal ulcers.
VIPoma (Choice E) is a rare tumor associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia that produces vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). Through its physiologic mechanism of action, VIP causes chronic and profound watery diarrhea, electrolyte disturbances (eg, hypokalemia, hypercalcemia), achlorhydria, alkalosis, flushing, vasodilation, and hypercalcemia, but not duodenal ulcers.

nbme_correct_explanation: Smooth muscle hypersensitivity is the most likely mechanism responsible for this patient's abdominal pain and diarrhea, which is most consistent with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). IBS is diagnosed using the Rome-IV criteria, which includes the presence of abdominal pain at least once weekly that is associated with (generally relieved by) defecation, along with a change in stool appearance or stool frequency (at least two of three required). IBS is further subdivided into IBS with constipation (IBS-C), with diarrhea (IBS-O), or mixed (IBS-M). IBS often presents with intermittent abdominal pain that is relieved by bowel movements and associated alterations in bowel habits with intermittent episodes of diarrhea and/or constipation. Features that are suggestive of underlying organic pathology rather than IBS include the presence of occult blood or melena, nocturnal diarrhea, ongoing diarrhea despite fasting, worsening abdominal pain, weight loss, or a family history of inflammatory bowel disease or colon cancer. While no consistent or definitive mechanism has been demonstrated to account for all patients with IBS, it is thought that those with IBS may have an increased sensitivity to regularly secreted cholecystokinin, a highly sensitive gastro-colic reflex, and/or a higher rate of baseline peristalsis. Other theories including the role of food sensitivities and mucosal inflammation are being explored as potential contributing factors. Treatment often requires a multimodal approach with dietary modifications, exercise, treatment of underlying anxiety or depression, and the use of medications such as anti-diarrheal medications or anti-spasmodic agents.

nbme_correct_explanation: Hepatobiliary obstruction often occurs from malignancy, classically presenting with painless jaundice and weight loss. There are many possible types, for example cholangiocarcinoma, pancreatic carcinoma, and hepatocellular carcinoma. Pancreatic adenocarcinoma commonly occurs in the pancreatic head. It is often initially characterized by nonspecific, vague abdominal discomfort or weight loss. As the mass increases in size, it can lead to the obstruction and dilation of both the common bile duct and main pancreatic duct, referred to as a double-duct sign on imaging. Obstruction of these ducts can result in painless jaundice (prevention of excretion of conjugated bilirubin), exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (impaired digestion and weight loss caused by prevention of excretion of pancreatic digestive enzymes), or pancreatitis (autoactivation of pancreatic enzymes). The nonspecific nature of pancreatic adenocarcinoma's early symptoms creates a diagnostic dilemma because many benign conditions present similarly. It is frequently asymptomatic until it creates an obstruction, gastrointestinal dysfunction, neural or vascular encasement/invasion, or metastatic disease. Initial diagnosis is made with CT scan of the abdomen, which can elucidate the cause of biliary duct obstruction and the extent of cancer or competing diagnosis (eg, hepatobiliary stricture).

Endotoxin is a component of the cell wall of gram-negative bacteria that is recognized by the host and leads to an inflammatory response. While endotoxin can contribute to sepsis and cause thrombocytopenia, neutralization of the endotoxin is not used to treat septic shock.

Methylprednisolone (Choice C) is used in the treatment of inflammatory conditions, such as asthma or COPD exacerbations. It is relatively contraindicated in active infections because it inhibits the host's immune response to infection. Steroids are indicated in infections in cases of relative or absolute adrenal insufficiency, and hydrocortisone is often used for this purpose in refractory septic shock, however this would follow the administration of fluids, vasopressors, and antibiotics, not before.

Platelets (Choice D) are not indicated in this patient. Gram-negative infections can lead to thrombocytopenia. However, platelet transfusion is not routinely recommended until platelet counts fall below 10,000/mm3 unless the patient is bleeding.

Whole blood (Choice E) is rarely used in clinical medicine. When used, it is most common during massive transfusion protocol to provide a patient with a balanced transfusion of red blood cells, platelets, and plasma in the setting of traumatic hemorrhage. This patient is only mildly anemic and thrombocytopenic and would not benefit from whole blood transfusion.

nbme_correct_explanation: A positive likelihood ratio is the likelihood that a patient with the disease will have a positive test result compared to the likelihood that a patient without the disease will have a positive test result. It can be calculated by dividing the sensitivity by (1-specificity). In contrast, the negative likelihood ratio is the likelihood that a patient with the disease will have a negative test result compared to the likelihood that a patient without the disease will have a negative test result. It can be calculated by dividing (1-sensitivity) by specificity. A likelihood ratio greater than one increases the post-test probability, whereas a ratio less than one decreases the post-test probability. In this case, a likelihood ratio of 1.0 indicates that the test would neither increase nor decrease the post-test probability, meaning that it would not be useful in diagnosing ovarian cancer in this patient.

If the test results are negative, you do not have cancer. A positive result is inconclusive," (Choice A) would be an appropriate response for a test that was 100% sensitive. Sensitivity refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those with the disease, such that a negative test can accurately exclude the diagnosis.
"If the test results are positive, you have cancer. If they are negative, you do not have cancer," (Choice B) would be the case for a test that was 100% sensitive and specific.
Sensitivity refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those with the disease, whereas specificity refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those without the disease.

nbme_correct_explanation: One of the core tenets of medical care is patient autonomy, or a patient's right to make decisions for themselves. This patient has terminal metastatic cancer and has failed multiple treatment options. At this point, transitioning to a more comfort-focused health care approach would be reasonable and in line with this patient's goals. As a terminally ill patient approaches the end of his or her life, he or she may decide to focus on the quality of his or her remaining life rather than on increasing the quantity of time remaining. This often allows them to avoid further invasive diagnostic and therapeutic interventions and to instead be as comfortable as possible for the remainder of their life when additional therapy would not meaningfully extend the quantity of remaining life. For this patient, the most appropriate next step would be to provide adequate pain control with intravenous morphine therapy so that she can be in as little pain as possible until death. Occasionally, a family's desires are inconsistent with a patient's desires for their care. If the patient has capacity to make medical decisions, his/her wishes should be honored, rather than those of their family. The physician should explore reasons for the discrepancy, especially in cases where values may have recently changed or in cases of impaired capacity, but barring any ethical uncertainty, patient wishes should be honored.
nbme_incorrect_explanation: Consulting with the hospital ethics committee (Choice A) is not necessary. This patient has a terminal illness and the mental capacity to make her own decisions regarding her care. Her desires for her care going forward should be prioritized over the desires of her family. Obtaining a psychiatric assessment (Choice B) would be inappropriate. This patient has no signs to suggest that she is incapable of making an informed decision regarding her goals of care going forward. With progressive metastatic terminal cancer, the decision to forego further attempts at life-sustaining treatments to focus on quality of life would be a reasonable decision. Intravenous chemotherapy (Choice D) and operative cytoreduction (Choice E) would not be in line with this patient's goals of care. She would prefer to abstain from further treatment in the setting of progressive metastatic disease, despite her family's desires because these treatments would be more likely to diminish quality of life without substantially adding to her quantity or remaining quality of life.

nbme_correct_explanation: Mild traumatic brain injury, also known as a concussion, commonly results in transient loss of consciousness, confusion, amnesia, headache, dizziness, nausea, and/or vomiting minutes after the injury. Symptoms that commonly develop within the following days include mood disturbances, photophobia, phonophobia, trouble concentrating, and/or insomnia. Focal neurologic symptoms such as limb weakness or vision changes may indicate traumatic neurovascular injury. As such, all patients with suspected concussion should undergo a thorough neurologic examination, and a subset of at-risk patients should receive neuroimaging, especially those demonstrating any neurologic deficits. All patients should be monitored closely for 24 hours for neurologic deterioration, which may indicate a developing intracranial hematoma. To prevent cumulative brain injury (eg, a second concussion), patients with concussion should return to their usual activities in a graded fashion, beginning with the return to school or work. Each day, a more intense activity can be introduced (eg, light aerobic exercise), culminating with contact sports after 1 week or more in uncomplicated and improving cases. Several clinical decision rules (eg, Canadian CT head rule for adults, Pediatric Emergency Care Applied Research Network {PECARNJ rule for children) exist to inform the need for neuroimaging following head injury. These rules are designed to be sensitive rather than specific; therefore, there are few false-negative cases when these rules are applied (and therefore a minimal miss rate of significant injury).
nbme_incorrect_explanation:
Basilar skull fracture (Choice A) refers to fracture of the bones at the base of the skull. Nausea, rhinorrhea, otorrhea, and hemotympanum are suggestive findings after a basilar skull injury. Cranial nerve dysfunction is also possible. Confusion is uncommon, and this patient does not have rhinorrhea or otorrhea.

Chronic subdural hematoma (Choice B) may present with the insidious onset of headache, lethargy, confusion, nausea, vomiting, seizures, and/or vision impairment. Chronic subdural hematomas most commonly occur in older patients. This young patient instead presents with the acute onset of neurologic symptoms following blunt head injury.

Epidural hematoma (Choice D) is classically associated with trauma to the middle meningeal artery and can present with an initial lucid interval followed by deterioration of mental status. Patients can also develop symptoms of headache, vomiting, seizures, and coma. This patient demonstrates an improving rather than a deteriorating course. Epidural hematomas can rapidly expand causing brain herniation syndromes.

Facial bone fracture (Choice E) commonly occurs as a result of direct blunt trauma to the face and is associated with pain and ecchymosis. Nerve or muscle entrapment and diplopia are possible. Loss of consciousness, confusion, and vomiting would be uncommon.

Frontal skull fracture (Choice F) is uncommon due to the hardness of the bone, but it can occur after severe blunt head injury and can be associated with intracranial bleeding. It can present with swelling, tenderness, a palpable skull defect or crepitus, and can be associated with altered mental status. This patient does not have a skull defect, swelling, or crepitus, and his mental status improved more rapidly than would be expected with a frontal skull fracture.

Intracerebral hematoma (Choice G) refers to hemorrhage within the brain parenchyma, which most commonly occurs secondary to hypertension. Patients can present with headache, vomiting, confusion, altered mental status, stupor, upper motor neuron signs, and focal neurologic deficits such as hemiparesis and hemisensory symptoms. This patient's quickly improving mental status and vomiting are inconsistent with intracerebral hematoma.
